articles.headline: A Family With Two Moms, Except in the Eyes of the Law
articles.snippet: Same-sex couples face difficulties in establishing legal ties not just to each other, but also to their children.
articles.abstract: Same-sex couples face difficulties in establishing legal ties not just to each other, but also to their children.
articles.lead_paragraph: Same-sex couples raising children must stand ready to prove to the world they are a family, just one that happens to have two mothers or two fathers.

articles.headline: Libor Case Documents Show Timid Regulators
articles.snippet: Documents released on Friday show that regulators balked at playing a more public role in reform efforts in 2008, and some British officials pushed back on certain fixes.
articles.abstract: Documents released on Friday show that regulators balked at playing a more public role in reform efforts in 2008, and some British officials pushed back on certain fixes.
articles.lead_paragraph: As an interest rate manipulation scandal grips the banking industry, regulators have defended their actions and trumpeted their efforts to overhaul the flawed system during the financial crisis.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Mark Scott

articles.headline: Tax Loopholes Block Efforts to Close Gaping U.S. Deficit
articles.snippet: Lawmakers point to ending tax dodges as the answer to much that ails the country, but one deficit hawk’s fight for a loophole benefiting his constituents shows how difficult that is.
articles.abstract: Lawmakers point to ending tax dodges as the answer to much that ails the country, but one deficit hawk’s fight for a loophole benefiting his constituents shows how difficult that is.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As a member of the “Gang of Six,” Senator Mike Crapo of Idaho has emerged as something of a hero among advocates of bipartisanship, one of three conservative Republicans working with three Democrats to cut the deficit by closing loopholes that allow businesses and households to avoid paying taxes.

articles.headline: In Zimbabwe Land Takeover, a Golden Lining
articles.snippet: The seizure of white-owned farms was a disaster for Zimbabwe on many levels, but amid that pain, tens of thousands of people got small farm plots and many ended up faring pretty well.
articles.abstract: The seizure of white-owned farms was a disaster for Zimbabwe on many levels, but amid that pain, tens of thousands of people got small farm plots and many ended up faring pretty well.
articles.lead_paragraph: HARARE, Zimbabwe — When Roger Boka started his auction business in the 1990s, this city’s tobacco trading floors were hushed places, save the mellifluous patter of the auctioneer. A handful of white farmers, each selling hundreds of bales of tobacco, arrived in sport utility vehicles, checking into the city’s best hotels while waiting for their big checks to be cut.

articles.headline: Liberal Donors Finding Home in Massachusetts Senate Race
articles.snippet: Elizabeth Warren’s haul — $24.5 million so far — has already catapulted her to No. 15 on the list of most successful Senate campaign money-raisers in history.
articles.abstract: Elizabeth Warren’s haul — $24.5 million so far — has already catapulted her to No. 15 on the list of most successful Senate campaign money-raisers in history.
articles.lead_paragraph: Elizabeth Warren has been so prodigious in raising money for her Senate campaign in Massachusetts that she is on track to become the top fund-raiser for the Senate this year, as well as one of the top Congressional fund-raisers of all time.

articles.headline: He’s Watching That, in Public? Pornography Takes Next Seat
articles.snippet: The use of computers, tablets and smartphones has given rise to growing public displays of pornographic content, a thorny issue for legislators, libraries and airlines to address.
articles.abstract: The use of computers, tablets and smartphones has given rise to growing public displays of pornographic content, a thorny issue for legislators, libraries and airlines to address.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — On a recent morning at the main public library here, dozens of people sat and stood at computers, searching job-hunting sites, playing games, watching music videos. And some looked at naked pictures of men and women in full view of passers-by.

articles.headline: A Nation That’s Losing Its Toolbox
articles.snippet: The waning of manufacturing in the economy may be resulting in a dilution of craftsmanship — long a vital ingredient in the American self-image as a can-do people.
articles.abstract: The waning of manufacturing in the economy may be resulting in a dilution of craftsmanship — long a vital ingredient in the American self-image as a can-do people.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y.

articles.headline: Swiss Freeports Are Home for a Growing Treasury of Art
articles.snippet: Business is thriving at Swiss freeports — those tax-free havens for valuables that are the closest thing to the Cayman Islands that the art world has to offer.
articles.abstract: Business is thriving at Swiss freeports — those tax-free havens for valuables that are the closest thing to the Cayman Islands that the art world has to offer.
articles.lead_paragraph: GENEVA

articles.headline: Ex-Romney Aide Steers Vast Machine of G.O.P. Money
articles.snippet: The 2012 campaign’s most influential strategist works out of an unmarked suite in an anonymous office park in suburban Virginia, and not for a candidate.
articles.abstract: The 2012 campaign’s most influential strategist works out of an unmarked suite in an anonymous office park in suburban Virginia, and not for a candidate.
articles.lead_paragraph: The most influential political strategist of the 2012 campaign works out of an unmarked suite in an anonymous office park in suburban Virginia, a few floors above a Japanese-themed steakhouse. He does not work for one of the presidential campaigns. He is not a pundit.

articles.headline: Into the Bailout Buzz Saw
articles.snippet: A damning account by Neil Barofsky, who tried to police the TARP bailouts, portrays regulators as captured by the very industry they were supposed to be regulating.
articles.abstract: A damning account by Neil Barofsky, who tried to police the TARP bailouts, portrays regulators as captured by the very industry they were supposed to be regulating.
articles.lead_paragraph: IT might seem remarkable that there’s more to say about our late Bailout Age. But there is more — a lot more.

articles.headline: From a Dark Theater, Tales of Protection and Loss
articles.snippet: Their families, bonded in grieving, recalled the victims of the attack at an Aurora, Colo., movie theater with a mixture of love and the numbness of disbelief.
articles.abstract: Their families, bonded in grieving, recalled the victims of the attack at an Aurora, Colo., movie theater with a mixture of love and the numbness of disbelief.
articles.lead_paragraph: AURORA, Colo. — Movie screen superheroes never die. But there were superheroes present in a darkened movie theater at the Town Center at Aurora mall, and some of them did die, like Matthew Robert McQuinn, who threw his body in front of his longtime girlfriend, Samantha Yowler, shielding her from the bullets that took his life.
articles.byline: By Erica Goode and Dan Frosch

articles.headline: Before and After Massacre, Puzzles Line Suspect’s Path
articles.snippet: James Eagan Holmes, 24, who is suspected of killing 12 moviegoers in Colorado, left behind a series of explosive traps in his apartment, the police said, and a litany of questions.
articles.abstract: James Eagan Holmes, 24, who is suspected of killing 12 moviegoers in Colorado, left behind a series of explosive traps in his apartment, the police said, and a litany of questions.
articles.lead_paragraph: AURORA, Colo. — Killing a dozen people and wounding more than 50 others was apparently not enough for James Eagan Holmes, according to the police. Inside his otherwise ordinary apartment lay an intricate series of explosive booby traps, seemingly designed to kill anyone who entered while pursuing his trail.
articles.byline: By Jack Healy and Serge F. Kovaleski

articles.headline: Stymied at U.N., U.S. Refines Plan to Remove Assad
articles.snippet: The United States has for now abandoned efforts for a diplomatic settlement to Syria’s conflict, and instead will add aid for opponents of President Bashar al-Assad.
articles.abstract: The United States has for now abandoned efforts for a diplomatic settlement to Syria’s conflict, and instead will add aid for opponents of President Bashar al-Assad.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration has for now abandoned efforts for a diplomatic settlement to the conflict in Syria, and instead it is increasing aid to the rebels and redoubling efforts to rally a coalition of like-minded countries to forcibly bring down the government of President Bashar al-Assad, American officials say.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt and Helene Cooper

articles.headline: U.S. Drug War Expands to Africa, a Newer Hub for Cartels
articles.snippet: The United States, trying to combat Latin American groups that are using Africa to smuggle cocaine into Europe, has begun training an elite counternarcotics police unit in Ghana.
articles.abstract: The United States, trying to combat Latin American groups that are using Africa to smuggle cocaine into Europe, has begun training an elite counternarcotics police unit in Ghana.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a significant expansion of the war on drugs, the United States has begun training an elite unit of counternarcotics police in Ghana and planning similar units in Nigeria and Kenya as part of an effort to combat the Latin American cartels that are increasingly using Africa to smuggle cocaine into Europe.
articles.byline: By Charlie Savage and Thom Shanker

articles.headline: Question for a C.E.O.: What Is Yahoo?
articles.snippet: While Yahoo is many things, it leads in media. To succeed, its new chief executive, Marissa Mayer, must come to grips with its sprawling array of content.
articles.abstract: While Yahoo is many things, it leads in media. To succeed, its new chief executive, Marissa Mayer, must come to grips with its sprawling array of content.
articles.lead_paragraph: What is Yahoo?

articles.headline: Facebook Efforts on Advertising Face a Day of Judgment
articles.snippet: As its share price has plummeted, Facebook has scrambled to attract advertisers away from Google. Its first earnings report since going public will indicate how it is doing.
articles.abstract: As its share price has plummeted, Facebook has scrambled to attract advertisers away from Google. Its first earnings report since going public will indicate how it is doing.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — In the race for digital advertising dollars, Google has been the clear winner, with its ability to customize advertisements based on what you search for. But Facebook, which customizes ads based on who you and your friends are, hopes to be a contender. An important test of how it is doing will come on Thursday, when it releases its first earnings numbers since going public.

articles.headline: Reports of Forced Abortions Fuel Push to End Chinese Law
articles.snippet: Accounts of women being coerced into late-term abortions by local officials have thrust a policy that penalizes families in China for having more than one child into the spotlight.
articles.abstract: Accounts of women being coerced into late-term abortions by local officials have thrust a policy that penalizes families in China for having more than one child into the spotlight.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Pan Chunyan was grabbed from her grocery store when she was almost eight months pregnant with her third child. Men working for a local official locked her up with two other women, and four days later brought her to a hospital and forced her to put her thumbprint on a document saying she had agreed to an abortion. A nurse injected her with a drug.

articles.headline: The Stylish Side of China
articles.snippet: Publishers of fashion magazines willing to contend with censorship and various other hurdles in China are being rewarded with heavy advertising demand.
articles.abstract: Publishers of fashion magazines willing to contend with censorship and various other hurdles in China are being rewarded with heavy advertising demand.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Zena Hao, a 24-year-old publicist, avid follower of fashion trends and proud owner of four Prada handbags, has a new passion: fashion magazines. She carries home hefty copies of Vogue and Harper’s Bazaar and studies the pictures for inspiration.
articles.byline: By Christine Haughney and Jonathan Landreth

articles.headline: Venture Capital Firms, Once Discreet, Learn the Promotional Game
articles.snippet: Venture capitalists are hiring full-time public relations experts to tell bloggers and reporters of their investing prowess.
articles.abstract: Venture capitalists are hiring full-time public relations experts to tell bloggers and reporters of their investing prowess.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — It wasn’t so long ago that venture capitalists kept secrets. The young start-ups they backed certainly sought attention, but most venture capitalists operated under levels of secrecy typically reserved for Swiss banks.

articles.headline: In ‘Paterno,’ Bad Timing for a Book
articles.snippet: Simon & Schuster is scaling back publicity for “Paterno,” an ill-timed biography of Joe Paterno, the disgraced Penn State football coach.
articles.abstract: Simon & Schuster is scaling back publicity for “Paterno,” an ill-timed biography of Joe Paterno, the disgraced Penn State football coach.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Thursday afternoon, the Free Library of Philadelphia was ready to go with a Sept. 6 event for Joe Posnanski, the author of “Paterno,” a forthcoming biography of the famed and vilified football coach.

articles.headline: Hedge Fund Places Faith in Euro Zone
articles.snippet: Marc Lasry, chief of the hedge fund Avenue Capital, sees a long-term opportunity in investing in the debt of troubled European countries.
articles.abstract: Marc Lasry, chief of the hedge fund Avenue Capital, sees a long-term opportunity in investing in the debt of troubled European countries.
articles.lead_paragraph: Marc Lasry has never been afraid to go his own way.

articles.headline: At Caterpillar, Pressing Labor While Business Booms
articles.snippet: Striking workers at an Illinois factory are protesting a call by the construction equipment manufacturer for a six-year wage and pension freeze amid record profits.
articles.abstract: Striking workers at an Illinois factory are protesting a call by the construction equipment manufacturer for a six-year wage and pension freeze amid record profits.
articles.lead_paragraph: JOLIET, Ill. — When it comes to dealing with labor unions, Caterpillar has long taken a stance as tough as the bulldozers and backhoes that have burnished its global reputation. Be it two-tier wage scales or higher worker contributions for health insurance, the company has been a leader in devising new ways to cut labor costs, with other manufacturers often imitating its strategies.

articles.headline: Republican Party in California Is Caught in Cycle of Decline
articles.snippet: With no one in statewide office, the California party, once a symbol of Republican hope and geographical reach, has stumbled as conservatives have prospered elsewhere.
articles.abstract: With no one in statewide office, the California party, once a symbol of Republican hope and geographical reach, has stumbled as conservatives have prospered elsewhere.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — This would seem a moment of great opportunity for California Republicans. The state has become a national symbol of fiscal turmoil and dysfunction, the Legislature is nearly as unpopular as Congress and Democrats control every branch of government.

articles.headline: Suspect Bought Large Stockpile of Rounds Online
articles.snippet: The 24-year-old man accused of killing a dozen people inside a Colorado movie theater gathered what the police called a 6,000-round arsenal legally and easily.
articles.abstract: The 24-year-old man accused of killing a dozen people inside a Colorado movie theater gathered what the police called a 6,000-round arsenal legally and easily.
articles.lead_paragraph: DENVER — Unhindered by federal background checks or government oversight, the 24-year-old man accused of killing a dozen people inside a Colorado movie theater was able to build what the police called a 6,000-round arsenal legally and easily over the Internet, exploiting what critics call a virtual absence of any laws regulating ammunition sales.

articles.headline: Top Afghans Tied to ’90s Carnage, Researchers Say
articles.snippet: The powerful men accused of responsibility, directly or indirectly, for tens of thousands of deaths are named in the pages of a monumental 800-page report.
articles.abstract: The powerful men accused of responsibility, directly or indirectly, for tens of thousands of deaths are named in the pages of a monumental 800-page report.
articles.lead_paragraph: MAZAR-I-SHARIF, Afghanistan — The atrocities of the Afghan civil war in the 1990s are still recounted in whispers here — tales of horror born out of a scorched-earth ethnic and factional conflict in which civilians and captured combatants were frequently slaughtered en masse.

articles.headline: Syria Threatens Chemical Attack on Foreign Force
articles.snippet: The warning appeared intended to ward off an attack by Western nations while also apparently confirming that Syria had chemical weapons.
articles.abstract: The warning appeared intended to ward off an attack by Western nations while also apparently confirming that Syria had chemical weapons.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syrian officials warned Monday that they would deploy chemical weapons against any foreign intervention, a threat that appeared intended to ward off an attack by Western nations while also offering what officials in Washington called the most “direct confirmation” ever that Syria possesses a stockpile of unconventional armaments.
articles.byline: By Neil MacFarquhar and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Spain’s Plight Helps Depress Global Stocks and the Euro
articles.snippet: Stocks on Wall Street traded lower as concerns about Spain’s financing problems plagued markets anew.
articles.abstract: Stocks on Wall Street traded lower as concerns about Spain’s financing problems plagued markets anew.
articles.lead_paragraph: Global stocks fell Monday and the euro dropped to its lowest level in two years as concerns about Spain’s financing problems plagued markets anew.
